awd_titl_txt: Process Intensification via Bijels for Simultaneous and Continuous Catalytic Reaction and Separation
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemical process intensification, driven by societal needs for sustainable manufacturing, exploits processes designed to reduce energy demand and minimize environmental impact. Membrane reactors that continuously perform simultaneous catalytic reaction and separation are an important example of this technology. When fluid phases separated by the membrane are of differing polarity (e.g., oil and water), oil-soluble reagents can be reacted and separated from aqueous-soluble products (and vice versa), further adding to the flexibility of these systems. Membrane reactors have had significant impact in the pharmaceutical industry because of the ability to immobilize enzymes as catalysts to drive biochemical reactions at oil/water interfaces within the membrane. Because enzyme-catalyzed reactions operate under mild conditions and pH, they are considered a green processing approach to the continuous reactive separation of pharmaceuticals. Membrane reactors could also reduce the environmental impact of agricultural fertilizers and herbicides by removing inactive or detrimental chemical species. Such processes could also impact the processing of vegetable oils to form specialty products for consumer products ranging from dietary supplements, infant formulas, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, food, and beverages. In these systems, however, interfacial area, which determines the rate of reaction, is limited to the oil-water interfaces in the membrane reactor pores. The objective of this research program is to transform the field of membrane-based reactive separations by introducing novel high-interfacial area structures with catalyst-laden interface areas (called bijels) as membrane elements. This material allows multiple key functionalities to occur in a thin layer, with remarkably high oil-water interfacial area estimated to be 100 times larger than conventional membranes. In this project, hydrolysis reactions of triglycerides to produce raw materials such as fatty acids and glycerol will be carried out in a bijel membrane reactor; this is an industrially significant process with an annual U.S. market in excess of $25B.

Bijels (bicontinuous interfacially jammed emulsion gels) are formed by quenching a miscible system through a critical point to induce phase separation. This quench occurs in the presence of nanoparticles, which form jammed layers trapped at the interface. High interfacial area is achieved because of the special, bicontinuous arrangement of oil and water in bijel membranes that allows interfacial area to increase with bijel membrane thickness. Furthermore, bijels have a sinuous continuous oil domain adjacent and intertwined with a sinuous, continuous water domain. The interface is stabilized and decorated with nanoparticles that can also support immobilized enzymes. The research team will build on their prior success in fabricating bijels and controlling their internal microstructure via a scalable method termed solvent transfer-induced phase separation (STRIPS). The researchers also will build on their collaboration with Pohang University of Science and Technology in South Korea in which batch mode reactive separation using an enzymatic catalysis was demonstrated. Based on these advances, the project objective is to develop bijel-based membrane reactors to facilitate heterogeneous enzyme-catalyzed reactions of reagents and products of differing polarity for continuous reaction and separation. Membrane reactor performance will be assessed using the lipase-catalyzed reaction of triglycerides with water to form glycerol and fatty acids. Specific aims of the research program include (1) studying the effects of STRIPS processing conditions on bijels; (2) demonstrating the continuous hydrolysis of esters through mathematical modeling and experiments; and (3) reduction of membrane transport limitations to create reaction-rate limited performance. The successful completion of this project will enable process intensification through the use of the novel nanostructured liquid films. The research team will learn how to optimally employ the bijel technology in processes of societal importance, including selective enantiomer production, production of specialty chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and fat splitting. Continuous enzymatic reactive separation in nanostructured bijels could have transformative impact on enantiomeric pharmaceutical production, a class of reactions with significant economic potential.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

There is a driving for process intensification in the chemical sector, or the development of energy efficient chemical processes that reduce the environmental footprint. We have developed bijel-based membrane reactors for process intensification to achieve simultaneous reaction and separation.  Bijels are structures made of sinuous channels of oil and water stabilized by a jammed layer of particles at the oil-water interface.  The water channels are all connected to each other; the oil channels are also all connected, making the structure bi-continuous. The oil-water interfaces are covered and stabilized by particles, typically silica nanoparticles whose surface chemistry is controlled to make them reside at oil-water interfaces. These nanoparticles form a jammed layer that prevents the interface from contracting. The juxtaposition of oil next to water with exceptionally high interfacial area makes these structures ideal for any process in which a chemical is transferred from one phase to the other.  Furthermore, upon cross inking the oil phase, bijels can serve as high surface area polymeric membranes with functional surfaces. In our work, we have gained control over bijel microstructure and developed them for separation and recovery of rare earth elements.

Prior to our research, bijel microstructure was widely known to be very difficult to control. We have developed significant improvement and can now make bijels with isotopically oriented features with control over nanostructure and microstructure.  Bijels are made by taking a solution of oil, water, and surfactants, adding nanoparticles, and adjusting conditions to make the solution unstable via a quench or abrupt change of a thermodynamic variable. Temperature changes are often exploited.  Upon quenching, the oil and water separate via a spinodal decomposition process, forming bicontinuous channels. Nanoparticles absorb on the interface and stabilize the structure.  The great advantage of this process is that the oil-water interfacial area in these structures is very high.  The disadvantage is that the phase separation, and resulting sizes of aqueous and oil domain sizes are difficult to control. Oil and aqueous regions are typically biased in orientation and heterogeneous in size. We have developed excellent control over these structural features by introducing a co-solvent (ethanol) to the precursor solution, whose controlled removal initiates the spinodal phase separation. We have developed a two-stage process for ethanol removal. In the first stage, we remove ethanol under water to form a tough skin on the bijel. In the second stage, we remove ethanol slowly in the vapor phase. This two-stage process allows the biased structural orientation to be avoided and domain size to be controlled.

We have identified bijels as promising media for rare earth element recovery. The rare earth elements (REEs) are a group of 17 elements mostly found in the earth’s crust. Their unique magnetic and luminescent properties make them essential in versatile advanced technologies, such as electric vehicles and wind turbines. Current REE purification methods by solvent extraction are neither green nor selective as they rely on separation using specialized molecules (extractants) and kerosine as oily phase.  Separating REEs from each other is notoriously difficult due to their similar chemical properties. We have studied how silica nanoparticles interact with REEs in order to use the nanoparticles to selectively capture these elements from solution.  We have identified three regimes of nanoparticle- REE cation interaction depending on solution pH.  At low pH, the nanoparticles are uncharged.  As pH is increased above the particle’s pKa, the nanoparticles become negatively charged and attract the highly positively charged REE cations. This is the electrostatic interaction regime. In this regime, the interactions between the nanoparticles and the REE is strong, but selectivity among REEs is poor. At higher pH, the REEs react with water to form a variety of hydrolysis products with reduced charge.  There are two interesting features to this regime.  First, the hydrolyzed REE form precipitates or skins on the surfaces of the nanoparticles. Second, the onset pH for the hydrolysis reaction differs among the REE. By tuning pH, REE can be selectively captured by forming the structure on nanoparticle surfaces, and released by dropping the pH, allowing the captured REE to be selectively eluted.
